column5: After having bottled hundreds of jars of pickles, preserves, salsa, etc..., I really look forward to bottling this last item so it is ready for Christmas. In the summer they look like this.   Wee little elderberries that I pick by the bushel. The last pick is set aside for myself, and it was a more abundant pick this year. Tonight they became one of my favourites.. Brandy   I still have salsa to bottle, but the brandy marks the end of the harvest season.

Nice work, and a lot of effort.  I did a lady a bit of a favour, picked 5 buckets of chokecherries and 4 small bucket of crabapples for her, she sent me a couple of samples. Very good tasting.  Seems like there were bumper crops for everything this year.
I' now theres a man after me own heart , now you would'nt be want'en to shares some of her woods ya ...............i  can just taste her now .

You've had a busy fall with all your preserves Bruce and hopefully you enjoy them all winter long.  My neighbor uses elderberries for jams & wines and although I haven't tried the wines, he gave me a couple jars of his jam and it's excellent.
After a bottle of that I should be, as they say, "pickled"  Truth is we would not be eating half as healthy if we were relying on the stoopermarkets.
What did you do to get the brandy? Did you vaporize the alcohol from the elderberry wine? I'm just curious cause I didn't know it got that dark. Sounds like you're right into it.
From mash there is a fair amount of boiling to do to thicken, plus a liberal amount of sugar to fortify.
How did you make it, if you dont mind me asking? I thought you had to distill wine to get brandy? Looks awesome either way thou.....
Nice work, I canned my first fish this year (Whitefish) its amazing, so good!
